comment._content: From en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhyl "A Rhyl landmark was the Pavilion Theatre, an ornate building with five domes, which was demolished in 1973 and the adjacent pier which was finally removed in 1972." But the five-domed building in a 1913 photo at www.francisfrith.com/rhyl/photos/the-beach-and-the-pier-1... has a different exterior. The building in the photochrom is shown in an 1892 picture www.francisfrith.com/rhyl/photos/the-pier-1892_30367/

comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] swang said, "But the five-domed building in a 1913 photo ... has a different exterior." That's because the Grand Pavilion, (first) built in 1891, was wiped out in a spectacular fire on September 14th, 1901.[1]  The Pavilion was rebuilt in 1907, and opened on July 30, 1908.[2] That dates this LOC Photochrom to 'earlier than Sept 14, 1901'. It appears that *many* old Rhyl photographs are dated based on these dates ;)

comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content:
The large crowd on the beach (left center) appears to be entertained at the "minstrel pitch".
"It was an area of the sands cleared for use by street entertainers (possibly to stop them wandering the streets). In early days it was a tradition for performers of this kind to be ‘blacked-up’ and sometimes the public referred to them cheerfully as, ‘the niggers’. They performed several shows a day, with the accent on comedy and music, while some members of the troupe or helpers moved among the audience collecting money." [1]
